maintopic: TREATY RESPECTING THE PRESERVATION OF INDUSTRIAL PROPERTIES.
TREATY RESPECTING THE PRESERVATION OF INDUSTRIAL PROPERTIES.
speechtext:
Before the Orders of the Day are called, I wish to mention to my right lion, friend that 1 observe a press despatch from Washington yesterday in these terms :
Washington, April 2, 1902. Secretary Hay and Mr. Raikes, secretary of the British- embassy today signed a treaty extending to the British colonies .he provisions of the original treaty between the United States and Great Britain for the preservation of industrial properties.
There was some such treaty more particularly with regard to trade marks in 1877; subsequently a treaty between France and Spain and other nations to which the United States and Great Britain also became parties at a later date. I understood that these two conventions already applied to the British colonies. I would like to know whether my right hon. friend has any information on the subject which he would like to give to the House V

maintopic: TREATY RESPECTING THE PRESERVATION OF INDUSTRIAL PROPERTIES.
speechtext:
The government has uo information whatever upon the subject, but of course its attention has been called to the despatch quoted by my hon. friend, and we have asked, and at this moment are expecting information with regard to it. Without having received any such information, I am quite sure of one thing; That whatever treaty has been concluded by Great Britain with the United States, would not



ipso facto apply to the colonies, but that the colonies will be left to decide for themselves whether or not they shall be parties to that agreement whatever it may be.

Mr. Speaker. At the hour at which I moved the adjournment of the debate last night, it seemed inadvisable to ask the House to listen then to the remarks which I feel it incumbent upon me to make in this debate. I would not have cared to enter into a discussion of the public questions of the day at this time, had it not been for some statements which have been made by gentlemen on the opposite side of the House in regard to two or three matters in which I am somewhat, personally concerned, and in which I have been taking considerable interest during the present administration. Hon. gentlemen opposite have made some statements in this debate which I cannot help characterizing as not only reckless hut rash, inasmuch as *they have shown thereby the lack of study of the condition of affairs and of what has actually occurred under the administration of the present government during the last few years.
First, let me say a word or two in regard to a matter which was brought up by my hon. friend and colleague the Minister of Trade and Commerce (Hon. Sir Richard Cartwright), when he spoke a week or two ago in this debate, in regard to certain figures pertaining to the census which has been taken by my department during the past year. Hon. gentlemen opposite alleged that my hon. friend the Minister of Trade and Commerce had made statements which could not be substantiated, and one hon. gentleman, the hon. member for Pictou (Mr. Bell) undertook to disprove some of those statements, and asked that further proof of them be submitted. I venture to think that my hon. friend the Minister of Trade and Commerce put this matter in an incontrovertible form before the House, so far as the broad question is concerned. The statements which he made did not go into such detail as could perhaps be called absolute and entire proof on every point; but they were sufficiently detailed. I think, to appeal to the mind of any unprejudiced individual who either heard or read them, and to prove his main contention, which was that the census cf 1801 was unduly swelled in the figures of population, and that therefore
speakername: The MINISTER OF AGRICULTURE (Hon. Sydney A. Fisher).

speakerposition: Prime Minister; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
comparisons on this point were unfair to the progress and prosperity of Canada during the last decade, and that it was necessary to show that these were unfair, or else the people of the world and the people of our own country, in studying the census, might not understand and appreciate to the full extent the immense progress which Canada has made in the last few years.
Now, Sir, I have under my hand a number of statements which go into greater detail than those submitted by my hon. friend. I venture therefore to supplement what he has stated by placing some of these statements before the House and the country. They are far too voluminous for me to read them all ; but I wish to read some specimen ones, which I have taken very much at random, amongst the many papers which were laid on the Table by the Minister of Trade and Commerce, and other statements which I have prepared. My hon. friend from Pictou claimed that in the taking of the census of 1891 extreme care had been taken by the government and the minister in charge of the department at that time to insist that the enumerations should be carefully and accurately made. He pointed out that, in so far as industrial establishments were concerned, the enumerators were instructed to include only those which had an annual output of $200. He therefore concluded that it was only such establishments that were included in the tabulation of the census of 1891, and that it was quite reasonable that industrial establishments yielding an annual output of $200 should be regarded as industrial establishments.
I have under my hand the instructions which were issued to the enumerators in 1891, and I find no such statement in those instructions. There was no instruction given to the enumerators that they should only include industrial establishments which gave an annual output of $200. As a matter of fact, that was the same instruction as was given in 1871, in 1881 and in this last census. I do not quarrel with that instruction, but I want to correct the impression that was conveyed by the remarks of my hon. friend from Pictou.
But, further than that, I find that in these tabulations not only did the enumerators take industrial establishments which had not an annual output of $200, but here in the bureau at Ottawa such establishments were included to a very large number indeed. I have in my hand the third volume of that census, which gives these industrial establishments. I have not undertaken to go through the whole 386 pages of that volume, but I did go through the first 80 pages, and as a specimen I find that in those 80 pages there are 339 industrial establishments included in the tabulation the product of each of which was less than $200- a pretty fair proportion, in fact a very large proportion of the whole number.
What Is the proportion of the whole number ?

I have not worked out the exact proportion ; but these 339 establishments had a total annual output of $44,500, or an average of $144 for each establishment, instead of $200. This shows that the industrial enumeration was not made on the basis which has been alleged.
But, Sir, there is a much more important part of the tabulation and the enumeration which I also want to go into, that is, for the population. Hon. gentlemen opposite and their friends in the country have been making certain criticisms of the census of 1901. In the first place, I may say that the instructions that were given in 1901 with regard to the enumeration were practically the same as the instructions given in 1891, 1881 and 1871. It is true there was one difference made in the census of 1891, which was pointed out by my hon. friend from Pictou, that difference being that people who had been absent for more than 12 months were not to be enumerated ; and my hon. friend took great credit to the government of that day for taking that precaution and thereby preventing the enumerating of people who had left the country or left the particular-locality permanently. Now, Sir, what have we found ? We have found, by a careful investigation, in so far as it has gone-and it has gone very far indeed in the province of Quebec, and a reasonable distance in the province of Ontario-that if that instruction was given, it was disregarded to such an extent that we must conclude that it was wilfully disregarded. The enumerators, some of them, ignored it entirely ; because I shall be able to show, not by .general statements of the number in the aggregate, but by individual statements, that many individuals and their families were enumerated who had been more than 12 months absent from the place where they were enumerated.

May I ask the hon. member a question ? Was not the first question of the enumerator this :	In the event of
any of the members of the family being away, do you expect them to come back ? In the event of their not being expected back, the next question was :	Have they
been away more than a year '? But in the event of the first question being answered in the affirmative, even if they were away five years, the enumerators would be obliged to include them.

There were no such instructions. The instructions were that if they were absent more than twelve months they should be held to be away permanently and should not be put on, but, as a matter of fact, they were put on in 1891 in numerous instances. In the census of 1901 the instructions were
that they should not be put on, and we have no proof or suspicion that any were included who were away more than twelve months.
Hon. gentlemen opposite have taken two positions on this question. First, they claim that the census of 1S91 was correctly taken and then they imply that the census of 1901 was not. The accusation is made that in the province of Quebec, in the census of 1901, the enumeration was excessive, that some people were counted who should not have been, and that in Ontario fewer people were counted than should have been on the schedules. I venture to say that I can prove that in the province of Quebec in 1901 no more people were enumerated than should have been, but that in the census of 1891 names were put on to an enormous extent that should not have been enumerated at all. If, therefore, there is any accusation of favouritism committed by either government in unduly swelling the population of the province of Quebec, that accusation comes with ill grace from Jion. gentlemen opposite, because it was really the late' government which was guilty. Let me cite a few instances just to show how the administration of these hon. gentlemen opposite proceeded in taking the census in 1891. Let me first say that in the investigation which I caused to be made, we found a ready means of obtaining information in the province of Quebec, where there is a large Catholic population. And I took care to have the investigation made in those counties in which the population is practically and .entirely Catholic, and not where there is a large mixed population. My hon. friend from South Lanark (Mr. Haggart) spoke of the counties of Drummond and Arthabaska, in which there is a mixed Catholic and Protestant population, and he argued that the reason of the disparity was that in the parochial census the Protestants were not included, but in the counties where I have had an investigation, the details of which my hon. friend the Minister of Trade and Commerce laid on the Table the other day, the county of Drummond and Arthabaska does not appear because we limited our inquiry to those counties where there is a homogeneous Catholic population and where, therefore, the census bulletins should give results similar to the parochial censuses.
In every case has the hon. gentleman observed this rule ?
Practically.
Practically-that is another thing.

The hon. gentleman knows perfectly well that there is no part of the Dominion, no matter where, where there are not some

people of a different religion from that of the majority, but the numbers are so small in the counties I have alluded to that they can be practically ignored. My hon. friend is not so familiar with the province of Quebec perhaps as some of those who come from that province, and know more about it.
An lion. MEMBER,, ) V e do not know very much about it.

That is a pity.
The MINISTER OF AGRICULTURE, As my right lion, friend says, that is a pity. Comparing the census taken by the late government in 1891 with the parochial statistics, we find that the numbers in the former were in every case much the larger, whereas in the census of 1901 there are four counties, namely, Bellechasse, Bagot, Port-neuf and Lotbiniere, where the parochial statistics are larger than those of the official census. In other words, if any error has been made by the census enumerators in 1901 it is due rather to their having failed to count all the people than to having unduly swelled the numbers.

Were these censuses taken at precisely the same period ?
I find again Norbert Charbonneau, aged 30, and his wife, aged 31, both have left the parish over fifteen years. Their children were also registered in the census of 1891. Aged 5 years, 3 year's, and 9 months respectively.
None of these people ever resided in St. Jean de Matha, yet their names appear in the census schedule.
Was this investigation made under oath ?
It was made by the parish priests.
That makes no difference.
It was made by people who knew the locality and had personal knowledge of the individuals who were living in the parish for years.
Mffien were these investigations made ?
Last year.
And the fifteen years date from last year ?

They were taken within three months of each other, and the figures I will give afford such glaring and convincing proof that no one can imagine for a moment that any difference could be due to any radical change in the population within that period. In these twenty-one constituencies, to which I have referred, the difference in 1891 between the official census and the parochial censuses is 40,000 to the. advantage of the former, or, very nearly 2,000 per constituency of an excess in the official over the parochial census. But in 1901, on the contrary, the difference is only 8,000, or about 400 per constituency.
I would ask the House to bear with me while I read a few of the details just to show in what way this enumeration was taken in 1891 and what were the results. I have here the returns from the county of Joliette, the evidence of the Rev. Mr. Morin, attested by Dr. Turgeon and Mr. Dugas. 1 am not making any general, statement, but taking individual instances and giving individual proofs, and .here is one of the first instances that I find :
Leon Charbonneau, aged 39, and his wife, aged 36, absent from the parish for at least the last fifteen years. Yet they are registered in the schedule of 1891 as being present and having six children, namely, Joseph, aged 10; Leon, aged 8; Elizabeth, aged 6; Lea, aged 4; Elise, aged 3, and Olive, aged 2. These people have been absent fifteen years, but they and their six children were registered, and not one of these children was born in that county.

Y'es. But it was only ten years between the two censuses,
Phillippe St. Ama, 34 years, and his wife, Athelia, were enumerated in 1891 though they never resided in St. Jean de Matha. Still they were counted with their four children, aged respectively 9 years, 6 years, T years, and 2 months. That family was absolutely unknown in that parish, never having lived there either temporarily or permanently.
Here is another instance :	Alexander
Houle, aged 42, and his wife, Mafie-Anne, aged 40. They left for the United States eighteen years ago, but still their names appear on the census schedules of 1891 together with those of eight children, aged from sixteen years down to two years. And two of these children appear in the schedule as having the same name, which strikes one as rather peculiar.
Onesime Cleremont, aged 36, and his wife, aged 34, were absent in the United States when the census of 1891 was taken, but their names and those of three children appear in the schedule.
A little further down we find the name of Onesime Cleremont, aged 38, and his wife, aged 39, and three children. The enumerator, not content with entering absentees once, counted them twice.
Then there is the name of Jean Baptiste Piette, aged 46, with those of his wife, aged 40, although they left St. Jean de Matha twenty years ago.
Their names appear on the census schedules, with two children-Marie Sara, aged 15 years;.

Melina, aged 13 years. Immediately alter the name of Jean Baptiste Piette and family, we find again Maxime Piette and Lea Piette, aged 33, with six children-Marie Louise, 'aged 14 years ; Rose Anna, aged 14 years ; Alexandrine, aged 12 years; Marie, aged 10 years; Joseph, aged 8 years; Napoleon, aged 6 years-which is a repetition of the same Maxime Piette and Lea Piette, already referred to as having left for the United' States 15 or 18 years ago.
Here again, the family, the father and mother and six children are reported twice over, and none of them ought to have appeared on the schedule list. I cannot read all these cases, but I am trying to read fair specimens.
Louis Roeheleau, aged 60, and his wife, Agathe, aged 56, are registered with five children : Joseph, aged 34; Louis, aged 36; Elie, aged 29, Alarie, aged 15, Nathalie, aged 17. But they have never resided in the parish, according to people who have never left the locality during the last 20 or 25 years. One old resident of St. Jean de1 Matha said that he remembered that about 40 years ago, one Louis Roeheleau was living in the parish, but he .'lever saw him since that time.
I would like to ask the name of the clergyman in that case.
Rev. Jean Baptiste Morin.
How long has he lived in that parish ?

I have no memorandum on that subject, but he has lived there for many years.
Paul Guilbault, aged 48, is regisfcred with his wife, Philomene, aged 30, and 18 children.
Hear, hear.

I wish hon. members to notice that the wife was 30 years of age, that her eldest sou, Joseph, was registered as 24 years of age. The other children were :
Elizabeth, aged 23; Marie, aged 22; Philomene, aged. 20; Pierre, aged 19; Olive, aged 18; Melina, aged 17, Armeline, agid 16, Paul, aged 15, Georges, aged 14; Miose, aged 13; Hormisdas, aged 12; EugSne, aged 11; Martin, aged 10; Ar-sgne, aged 9; Albert, aged 8; Norbert, aged 8; Marie-Anns, aged 3 months.
The father was 48 and the wife 30, with 18 children, and all were registered.
But Paul Guilbault and his wife and his alleged children have never resided in St. Jean de Matha. It is said in the locality that the same Onesime Plouffe above mentioned in this report had a son-in-lawr by the name of Guilbault. He was residing, at that time, at St. Damieu, in the county of Berthier, but he has left many years ago for the United States, and has never come back to the country. He has never resided in St. Jean de Matha.
This is another specimen of the way the census was stuffed in the province of Quebec in 1891. I have a number more here,
but I will not detain the House by reading them,
Go on.

All right. I will take another at haphazard :
Alem Parent, aged 23, is registered with his wife, Marie-Louise, aged 18, and their daughter, Rose-Alba, aged 4 months. Alem Parent is the son-in-law of Jean-Baptiste Layer, who was residing in St. Jean de Matha in 1891. Parent himself has always been living in St. Beatrix and never in St. Jean de Matha. This did not prevent the enumerator from registering him and his family twice. The second time he was recorded as follows : Olem Parent, aged 21; Marie Louise Parent, his wife, aged 19, and Rose-Anna, their daughter, aged 3 months.
Olivier Belanger, aged 42, is registered with his wife, Celina, aged 35, and four children : Joseph, aged 8; Henry, aged 7; Albina, aged 5, and Arthur, aged 3. These people are absolutely unknown to the old residents of the1 parish. They are probably some relatives of Mrs. Emelie Robillard, an old lady of 70 years old, who then resided in St. Jean de Matha. But if Olivier Belanger and his family ever lived in the parish, it is over twenty years ago.
And so on.	[DOT]
Go on.
The hon. gentleman (Mr. Hughes, Victoria) wants me to go on, but I have cases from other counties here that I want to give.
Will the hon. minister lay on the Table the names of the enumerators in each case ?
I will look up the name.

Will the hon. gentleman name the enumerator charged with this fraud ? And I would like to ask also whether he has made inquiries of the enumerators in any of these cases, and, if so, in which, and what answers has he got ?
I shall be glad to look up the names and lay them on the Table.
Has the hon. minister made inquiry of the enumerators charged with this fraud ?
In some cases that has been done.
Has It been done in this particular case ?
I cannot, at this moment say as to that.
Does not the hon. minister think it would have been fair to ask an explanation before making this charge on the floor of this House ?

The probability is that when an enumerator

lias made such an exhibition as that, his evidence would not be worth taking. I have here some, cases from the county of Bagot also. In St. Liboire we find the same kind of thing occurring to a very great extent. Here is one item I would like to read :
The stuffing in the town of Acton Vale and in the Parish of St. Andre of Acton, is probably larger, and the evidence of it is absolutely undeniable. Mr. J. E. Marcil, M.P., for Bagot, has resided in Acton Vale for the last forty years, and for thirty years he has been engaged in. business either as a clerk or as a merchant. He had consequently every opportunity of knowing every one in the locality. Mr. Marcil examined in our office the schedules of 1891 and has pointed out to us the names of those who had left the town of Acton Vale or the parish of St. Andre of Acton many years previous to the census of ten years ago.
Then the names are given [DOT]
Joseph Gagnon, aged 24, son of Alderic Gagnon and of Sophie Gagnon, is registered in the census book, but has not resided in the town of Acton Vale for the last fifteen years.
Leon Mousseau, aged 24, and Alexandre Mousseau, aged 21, both sons of Bdnonie Mousseau and Genevieve Mousseau, are registered on the census book, but have left the locality for over fourteen years.
Parmelie L'Heureux, aged 24, daughter of Leon L'Heureux, appears on the census book, but has not been living in Acton Vale for the the last sixteen years.
Louis Favreau, aged 26; Louise Favreau, aged 14; Dorinda Favreau, aged 21; Eustache Favreau, aged 20; Georges Favreau, aged 18; Charles, aged 31; Marie, aged 11; Delima, aged >0; Johnnie, aged 28; Angele Favreau, aged 47, and John Favreau, aged 35, are all sons and daughters of Louis Favreau and Angele Favreau. They appear in the census book but they were all born in the United States, and have never resided in Acton Vale.
Clara Lambert, aged 19, and Mary Lambert, aged 19, daughters of Pierre and Celima Lambert, are registered, but they had gone to the United States many years previous to the census of 1891.
Joseph Leveillee, aged 43, and his wife, aged 26, are registered with eleven children
Who makes that report ?
Mr. Marcil.
Who is Mr. Marcil ?
The present member for Bagot.
Oh, oh.

Who knows the county so well that he has been elected as a Liberal, the first time in many years that a Liberal could be elected there.
The enumerators in the parish of St. Ephrem d'Upton have not been more scrupulous ten years ago than in some other localities in the county of Bagot. Here follow's a list of persons who should not have been registered on the census book.
Was any explanation asked of this enumerator ?
1 cannot tell which were asked for an explanation and which were not.
Does the hon. minister know that any were asked ?

Yes. I will take also the county of Rouville in which a most extraordinary condition of affairs was shown.
In the county of Rouville there were 3,123 people enumerated on the Dominion census

more than the parochial census of the same year showed. This is the way in which the work was done in the village of Canrobert:
Pierre Reiadeau, aged 44, and his wife, One-sime, aged 37, are reg stered with eight children: Philias, aged 17, Emma, aged 15, Arthur, aged 13, Rosanna, aged 11, Maria, aged 9, Azarie, aged 7, Thais, aged 5, Fiorina, aged 3 ; that family have left Canrobert village 14 or 15 years ago.
Julien Coiteux, aged 58, and his wife Octavie aged 50, are registered with seven children : Napoleon, aged 22, Zephirine, aged 21, Emma, aged 19, Octavie, aged 17, Louis, aged 16, Joseph, aged 13, Delia, aged 11 ; that family were not residing in Canrobert.
Here follows a list of persons entered in Richelieu village who should not have appeared at all, because they all lived in the United States or had gone to other parts of the province more than twelve months previous to the census of 1891. The list is given here, with the names and details.
Who makes that report 7
This was made by the parish priest.
What is his name ?
His name is not here. Then I have the county of Lotbiniere, another one of the same character.

I do not wish to be constantly interrupting the hon. gentleman, but in any of these places where he lias made inquiries of the enumerator and has received an answer, will he be good enough to state it, in connection with his other remarks.
I told the hon. gentleman a little while ago that I could not lay my hands on the information to show which enumerators inquiries were made from and which were not.

Would the hon. gentleman be able at some subsequent stage to give us that information ?
The	MINISTER	OF	AGRICULTURE.
I will try to.

We would like to have that.
The	MINISTER	OF	AGRICULTURE.I have	thus far pretty	completely showedthe result of the investigations in the province of Quebec. As I said at the beginning, these	investigations	have been conducted
comparatively easily because of the peculiar conditions in that province which enabled us to get, not only the general figures, but the absolute details and statements of the individual.
Would the hon. gentleman allow me to ask him a question ?
Certainly.
I understand from the statements he has read now, he wants to show that a large number of French families in the province of Quebec were enumerated in 1891 that should not have been ?
I was not particular to say that they were French, but as a matter of fact I think they all were French.

I would like to draw the hon. gentleman's attention to a statement he made when the Cote circular was before this House two years ago. The hon. gentleman stated then that the French families of the province of Quebec were not properly enumerated, that a large number of families were not taken in that census of 1891 ; and that for the purpose of getting at the correct number of French families in the province of Quebec this circular was issued by Mr. Cote. How do these two statements coincide ?

There was a statement made that in the province of Quebec a large number of people that ought to have been enumerated were not enumerated. Our investigation shows that whether that was the case or not, a very large number of people were enumerated that ought not to have been enumerated. The two statements do not conflict at all. It may well have been that people who ought to have been enumerated were not enumerated, but at the present time I have given proof that hundreds and thousands of people were enumerated who had no right to be enumerated.
Will the hon. gentleman explain to us how these parties were enumerated that should not have been enumerated other than those he now mentioned ?

I will go on with my argument, if the hon. gentleman will allow me, at a later stage perhaps he may speak and say what he wants to. Now we did not wish to confine the investigation by any means to the province of Quebec. Although the difficulties were much greater in the province of Ontario, still a slight investigation was made to find out whether anything like the same conditions obtained. I may say at once that we did not find anything like as much of this sort of thing in the province of Ontario as we did in the province of Quebec. Whether the difficulties in Ontario were so great that we could not get at the facts, or whether there were no such errors committed, I am not prepared to say ; but I state frankly that the difficulties of obtaining this information in Ontario are much greater than they are in Quebec. Now we chose five places in Ontario for that in-

vestigation, they were chosen at hap-hazard, we chose them without knowing in the slightest degree what the results were going to be, we chose them chiefly for the reason that they showed certain inconsistencies in the figures, they showed that while the number of families had increased and the number of dwellings had increased, the population had decreased.
That is reasonable.

It is very unfortunate, if it is so, and it is rather an extraordinary condition of affairs. One of these five places was the township of Thurlow and the city of Belleville. A slight investigation showed that the census seemed to have been correctly taken there, there was nothing to show that there had been any stuffing of the lists. But in the other four places there did appear to have been stuffing, in Huron West, in Goderich and Clinton we found errors of that kind. In Goderich we found sixty-three persons out of 3,839 who ought not to have been there, and in Clinton, thirty-eight persons out of 2.633 who ought not to have been there, with an undue swelling of the list hy 1-7 per cent and 1-5 per cent. In North Middlesex-
Before the hon. gentleman reads that, will he say who gave that statement ?
Mr. D. F. Macpherson, and he gives the names of the individuals, and all about them. [DOT]
Let us have the names.

I am not going to read them all, I will lay the names on the Table. I will read a few :

Would the hon. gentleman permit me to ask him if the report Hon. Mr. FISHER.
states that these parties were away more than one year ?

In Cornwall. I venture to say that it accounts to a large extent, if not entirely, for the fact that in the comparisons of the growth of the population the growth from 1891 to

just as many people as they desire to do because there are no immediate means except by the local knowledge of some other individual of laying your finger on a man who was reported as being present or who might not be present. And my hon. friend from Toronto brought forward in his speech a little while ago a rather specious argument, the fallacy of which, I should think, the hon. gentleman must have been aware of, because I would naturally give him credit for enough intelligence to recognize it. I -did not expect to have to impute to him disingenuousness in putting the argument forward. He stated tha-t in the live years preceding the preference the aggregate of British imports into Canada were $1S7,000,000, and that from 1897 to 1901 inclusive, the aggregate was $186,000,000-practically the same. He put this forward as proof that the preference had done no good. Surely, the hon. gentleman knew perfectly well that the aggregate in -the first live years was an aggregate of yearly importations into Canada which were steadily decreasing from $43,000,000 in the first year to $29,000,000 in the last year, while the -aggregate in the succeeding five years was made up of importations which began at about -the lowest figure of the first five years and went on increasing. The one was,an aggregate composed of amounts on a descending scale, the British importations gradually and pretty rapi-dly tending toward the vanishing point, and the other of amounts which were steadily rising, and had got back -in five years to just about the place from which the policy of -hon. gentlemen opposite had lowered them. Sir, that is a fair specimen of the kind of -argument and manipulations of figures to which hon. gentlemen opposite descend in order to prove their contention. I was surprised, I confess, that the hon. gentleman from Toronto should make an argument so disingenuous unless, he was so obtuse that he could not see the fallacy in it.
Now, the hon. gentleman opposite spoke a few minutes ago -about one of these articles I have read over as being the only one in which we did anything for -the export trade to England. I suppose the hon. gentleman alluded to the trade in butter, which even hon. gentlemen opposite confess, has been
enormously stimulated and improved since their time, and which could not be improved under the old condition of affairs, because butter from Canada could not be carried to England and placed on the market there in good condition owing to the condition of transportation that obtained under the administration of hon. gentlemen opposite. Since that time, however, things have changed.
I want to point out that in respect of those articles I have alluded to we have done an enormous amount of work of which, perhaps, the House and the country are not aware. During the last five years what I may call the educational side of the Department of Agriculture has been greatly enlarged. We have been able, by the addition of some officers to our staff, though I must confess at some considerable expense, to reach the farmers and producers throughout the country in a way that was never even attempted before ; we have been able by the distribution of information from the Experimental Farm and from the agriculture and dairying branch under Professor Robertson, to disseminate information, to bring new points to the attention of the people, and help them to overcome the difficulties in their various industries. This has resulted in the increase of our cattle trade with Great Britain, taken in connection with the admission of free corn to feed their cattle, and it has resulted in the increase of the cattle trade with the United States by removing the quarantine impediment which had effectually shut out our cattle from the United States market. We have appointed a live stock commissioner who is to-day organizing -the live -stock interests in this country, and enabling those engaged In that interest to work together, to understand the situation of their trade, and better to overcome the difficulties which they encounter. We have stimulated the fruit trade by the passage of the Fruit Marks Act, which, though only in operation one year, has already done something to improve our export trade in fruits, by the appointment of inspectors under that Act to supervise the trade, by arranging for proper ventilation of the holds of steamers which cross the Atlantic, to carry our fruits and cheese in a proper condition, by arranging for cheese curing rooms, and the improvement of cheese curing in this country, which is only beginning to-day, but which has been necessary for a couple of years past, and which we have been working the people up to during the last two years. We have established a complete and continuous chain of cold storage from the creameries in Canada to the retailers in Great Britain, and that has been done so effectually that the butter trade of Canada is to-dav fivefold what it was in 1896. These 'things have been done by the department without much ostentation, hut they have resulted in stimulating production and improving the exports.

Now, I have here a few details which I wish to give in reply to some strictures that were made by the hon. member for South Wentworth (Mr. Smith). That hon. gentleman said that I had not done my duty because I had not compelled every steamboat that sails from a Canadian port to put in fans, &c. Now, Sir, the hon. gentleman is crediting my department with a great deal more power than it possesses. We have no power to compel any steamship company to do anything against their will ; though we have power to offer them inducements, we can show them the advantages they will reap from making these improvements. I found that difficulty from the commencement of my work. As a result of the representations that were made to one of the largest steamship lines, I was able to induce them to put in mechanical cold storage apparatus which, until that time, had never been put in any sliiji sailing from Canada. The result was the stimulus of the butter trade, followed by experiments in regard to the export of fruit, and this also offered prospects of improving the condition of the poultry meat exports, which have already grown to considerable proportions. When I found there was a necessity for proper ventilation in the holds of the vessels for the carriage of apples and cheese I exercised some pressure to induce the steamship companies to make the arrangements necessary, and succeeded to some extent. I went further than that. Last year I endeavoured to get the steamship companies to put in cooling apparatus by which the air would be artificially cooled in special chambers, and in that state forced through the holds where the fruit and cheese were stored. I was not successful with all the steamship companies at first, and I am condemned for that. X would like the hon. gentlemen opposite to tell me how I could compel the steamship companies to do this. Hon. gentlemen do not reflect that these are independent companies who trade for their own benefit. I went to the head of one of these companies in England, and represented the necessities of the Canadian trade. I asked him if he would not put in one of these cooling apparatus into the holds of each of his vessels in which butter and cheese were carried. I had already been in communication with his agents in Montreal, who had recommended to him that it should be done, but the head of the firm in England refused to do it. When I went there last summer I asked him to do it and he said he would not. Although I urged him, he still refused, and then I said, ' well, I have only one resource left, I will publish to the people of Canada who ship these goods across the Atlantic, that while your competitors do make these arrangements in their vessels to meet the demand of the Canadian trade, you refuse to do so ; and I will see, and you will see, whether the shippers of Canada will patronize your boats.' But my arguments had no influence with him. The moment that Professor Robert-Hon. Mr. FISHER.
son and I came back from England. I instructed Prof. Robertson to meet the shippers at Montreal who were engaged in shipping these goods, and he told them that this company had refused to meet our demands. At once I got a cable from the company, asking me how it was that I authorized a Dominion officer to do this, and I replied that it was necessary in the interests of the exporters and shippers of Canada. Tc-day that company is fitting up their ships, because they do not dare to go contrary to the demands of the Canadian trade and shippers of these goods.
Did that company give reasons for their refusal ?
The reasons were that they did not think it would pay, now they do think it will pay.
I did not catch the name of the company.
I did not give the name, I do not think it is wise to give it. I will give the name to the hon. gentleman privately, but I do not think it right to publish the name of the company to the public.
I think the hon. gentleman should not make the statement unless he is prepared to give the name of the company.
Would the hon. gentleman say whether the government were repaid as well for the sum they expended in fitting out these steamships with cold storage V

Yes, the money paid for them was refunded.

This particular line which was referred, to by the hon. member, for South Wentworth was under contract to supply certain vessels. They put on those vessels which the fruit-growers of Nova Scotia declared were suitable vessels. They, for their own convenience and for their own purposes, sold two of these vessels and they offered to put on other inferior vessels. The result has been that they have not been paid their subsidy and I venture to think that the hon. Minister of Trade and Commerce will not pay them their subsidy until they provide the accommodation which they are required to provide by the contract and which is needed by the trade. We have no means of compelling these companies. We can only hold inducements out to them that certain things are necessary to accommodate the trade of the country. We can describe what things are necessary and help them to meet these requirements. If they refuse to do it we have nothing more to do with them. If they will do it, we can give them the assistance which it has been the policy of this government to give for the purpose of inducing these companies to provide the necessary facilities. But, they have provided these facilities to a great extent. There were live main lines plying to Montreal during last season. Twenty-eight steamers have been fitted up and others are being fitted up today so as to be in readiness for the season of 1902. There were 77 sailings from Montreal last year with exhaust fans for the ventilation of their cargo space. We also induced the fitting out of four steamers with cold chambers rto force air through. Canada, with one exception, that of the line from Bristol to the West Indies which was subsidized lately by the home government, is the only country that has obtained vessels fitted out in this way for the carriage of cheese and fruit. We opened these negotiations last year and the result was that four steamers were fitted out as a trial and these steamers were so successf ul and our products were carried so well that this winter the main line companies are fitting out more vessels. Ten others are under way and it is expected that they will be fitted out for this season. These things are directly in the line with what I have been describing. These are the things that the hon. member for South Wentworth ignored while he quoted one particular case down in Nova Scotia. During the season of 1901 there were from the port of Montreal 254 sailings of ships. My officers reported on and inspected 204 of these sailings.
How many ships 7

1 cannot tell the hon. gentleman how many ships there were. But these were the sailings. There were so many sailings of the ships from Montreal. It does not matter very much whether one ship made forty trips or four. The other fifty sailings which 69
were not inspected were at the commencement of the season when there were none of these products going forward. We supervised and inspected and reported on every sailing of the regular line ships that went forward from Montreal last year, we have the records of all of these sailings in the department. We placed in these ships self-registering thermometers which could record the temperature in the cold storage chambers and the ships' holds during the voyage. These instruments were taken out of the ships bn their arrival at the ports in England by our officers who recorded the temperatures shown by the thermometers. We have a complete record of these temperatures. The hon. member for South Wentworth said we ought to do that. It has been done for three years past.
Could the hon. member give the House the value of the goods shipped by these sailings 7

I have not the value of them. All the butter shipped from Canada practically went by these sailings, as well as the fruit that went from Montreal and the cheese during last season. This was so much thought of aud so well liked that I was gratified to receive a resolution from the Montreal Board of Trade and a letter from the buyers of these products in England. The following is a resolution from the Butter and Cheese Association of the Board of Trade, Montreal
The members of this association have noted with gratification the complete success of the cold air chambers system used on some steamers running from this port during the past season, and they feel they cannot exaggerate the importance of having it installed in every vessel carrying dairy produce from1 here next season. It is certain that having experienced the benefits of the cooled chambers last season the great majority of British buyers will next year insist on having all goods shipped in these chambers. The demand is likely, therefore, to far exceed the supply unless some effort is made to induce the steamship companies generally to turn all their 'available cheese carrying space into cold air chambers. This association believes it would be immensely to the advantage of the whole dairy interest were there np other way of shipping possible, than in cooled chambers, and it would heartily join in all efforts made to accomplish this result.
This is another communication which came to me from the Home and Foreign Produce Exchange, Limited, of London, Eng. :
A few steamers sailing from Montreal to London have been fitted with cool air ventilators, which have proved a great success >n carrying Canadian cheese, and it is the opinion of the undersigned that the best interests of cheese Importers would be served if all steamers catering for the cheese trade were so fitted. It is also the opinion of the signatories that even during the winter months ;t would he desirable to continue this system1, as it is well known that heating in steamer's hold is caused by storage near other cargo, which has a tendency to create heat. The signatories would be glad



If the committee of the Home and Foreign Produce Exchange would take the matter up, with a -view to furthering the end suggested.
The importance of these representations will be appreciated from the fact that the memorial has been signed by practically all the London firms importing cheese.
Now that the matter has thus been brought to your notice, I would urge that no effort should be spared to give effect to the wishes of the trade.
Yours faithfully,
Chairman.
Do the bon. gentleman's contracts not cover the whole season V
The contracts covered all the trips that the ships made.
Well, then, that letter has not much point.

This is the kind of work that is being done. I want to say a word or two in regard to the cheese trade, a trade which has been the glory and the boast of the people and particularly the farmers of Canada for many years. We have made notable progress in this trade which commenced so many years ago. Many years ago, by the enterprise of the people of Ontario chiefly In the beginning, this trade obtained a high position and it maintained that position ever since until last year. Unfortunately, last year, in consequence of the heating of the cheese in the cheese factories, in the storing rooms here and during transportation, the cheese of Canada did not have as good a reputation on the English market as it had before.
Will the hon. gentleman
The cheese makers say that is not so.

The cheese makers will not say that is not so, in the presence of myself, or of Prof. Robertson, or of the experts who carried on the experiments I have referred to. I have stated the same thing at the Eastern Dairymens' Convention which was held at Whitby. Mr. Ruddick also went to the Western Dairymens' Convention at Woodstock this last fall, and (he laid the same facts before that great dairy convention where the best dairymen of the Dominion congregated, and the result was that the people begged us to put in practice the new scheme which was suggested to them for trying to get over that difficulty. Not one single man in either of these great conventions stated what the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clancy)-without knowing anything about it-dares to state here.
Hear, hear.

I venture to tell the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clancy) that the Eastern and Western Dairymens' Associations for the province of Ontario, represent the farmers and the dairymen of this country far more than he does, and that they know more about the cheese business than he.

I did not give that statement as my own opinion at all. I told the minister that the cheese makers generally denied the statement, and they point out that long before the hon. gentleman's cold storage business they had established the Canadian cheese trade in England.

The hon. gentleman (Mr. Clancy) does not yet know the difference between the cold 69*
storage system, and that cool storage necessary for the carriage of cheese.
I know it quite well.

The hon. gentleman (Mr. Clancy) has made a statement which is not supported by the facts. If the dairymen of Ontario agree with the hon. gentleman, how was it, that at the dairy convention at Whitby where there were assembled COO or 700 of the best dairymen of the province of Ontario, there was not a word of dissent when the statement was made before them by myself V If the hon. gentleman is right, how is it that at the Western Dairymens' Convention in Woodstock nothing of that kind was said by the men who are the leaders in this work, and who placed the cheese trade of Canada where it is to-day, while the hon. gentleman (Mr. Clancy) has never had anything to do with it ? I venture to say that the people of Canada; I venture to say that the members of this House will agree with me, that the men who assembled at these dairymen's conventions know more about the cheese trade than does the,hon. gentleman.
I suppose it is not necessary for me to repeat that I did not make that assertion on my own knowledge ?
No, but you said it was stated to you by the leading cheese makers of the country.
Quite so.

I say that the leading cheese makers of this country are represented in the dairymen's *conventions in the province of Ontario, and that any cheese makers who do not come to" these conventions are not the leading cheese men of this country.
Now, Sir, we are hoping to get over this difficulty and we are prepared this season to try the experiment of central aceum-mulating rooms for the assembling of the cheese for curing purposes. That scheme was laid before these two dairy conventions in Ontario, and it was also laid before the dairy convention of the province of Quebec. It was accepted by the dairymen who were present at these conventions as being a first rate scheme. They endorsed the carrying out of the experiment which Is to be carried out this season, and so far were they satisfied with it that I have had application after application from people all over this country asking for information as to how they could carry it out at their own expense if they had to -do so, but still more so requesting for information as to how to get the department to carry it out in their particular district.
Now, Sir, I have gone over these facts in general terms, and also to a certain extent in detail. I have laid them before the House because I wish that hon. members and the people iof the country generally

should appreciate and understand, that while nobody on the government benches, least of all myself, wish in any way to claim credit for the enormous crops of Canada during the last few years; crops which have been so instrumental in stimulating the /trade of this country; nevertheless we do believe, and I venture to say that I am prepared to give proof of it at any time and anywhere : that in Canada to-day, the government through the department over which I have the honour to preside, has been able to do a great deal to help, and to guide, and to direct the work of the farmers of this country, so that that work has been made more profitable to them than it was in days gone by. That is all X do claim and I think I can prove that claim. I believe that the trade returns show it; I believe that the records of the prices obtained for our exported products in the old country markets show it, and therefore I leave the matter in the hands of the House.
Now, Sir, I am not going to delay the House much longer. I am glad to have had the opportunity of saying a few words on this question. We have to-day an apparently clear cut division between the opposite sides of the House. We have the decision of the government that they should not make any changes in the tariff. Hon. gentlemen opposite, through the mouth of the leader of the opposition, have put forward an amendment to the motion of my hon. friend the Minister of Finance.- It seems to me, Sir, that with the record of the last five years of the commerce and trade of Canada; with the record of the material development in the country; with the record of the prosperity which has reigned in every branch of business, in every industry of this country, amongst the great classes of producers-it seems to me that the principle embodied in the saying to let well enough alone, is the one that ought to guide us at the moment. If difficulties arise in the progress of the country, or in the condition of its trade, or its industrial development, and the government can do anything which seems to them likely to help that progress and development, to help consumers as well as producers, it would be no doubt their duty to take the situation into consideration. But with such a record as we have had during the past five years, with people coming into the country by the thousands to make this country their home, and with the productions of the country going out in such enormous quantities and bringing in such magnificent returns to build up this country, it seems to me that it would be a great mistake for us to change the condition of affairs which has brought these magnificent results about. Hon. gentlemen opposite say that nothing that the government has done has brought them about. The government have been in power five years and more. In 1807 we inaugurated a fiscal Hon. Mr. FISHER.
policy which was signalized by a reduction of the duties, and by a preference which has given us a great advantage in the English market, as it has given our fellow-countrymen in the old land an advantage in our market. The results of this policy seem to be magnificent in any way you look at them; and with this fact before our eyes, I cannot see that it is necessary or that it would be good policy to make| a change now. If in the future any changq is required, let the future take care of itself; but let the present conditions continue as they are, and I believe the material advancement of the country will go on as it has done so splendidly during the past five years.

Mr. Speaker, before proceeding to discuss the resolution which is immediately before the House, I will, like a great many others, digress a little to deal with the question of the census, which has been so largely dealt with by the hon. gentleman who has just taken his seat, and to answer some of the accusations which have been made by that hon. gentleman. I take some interest in the census, having been myself a chief officer for twenty-two counties in the eastern part of the province of Ontario, and I wish to say emphatically that the twenty-two commissioners under my charge who were brought here to receive their instructions from Mr. St. Denis, were most particularly directed to guard against any inaccuracies in taking the census. They were so carefully directed that that gentleman said to them : ' When you go home to instruct your enumerators, if you find that there is anything that you do not understand, communicate with Mr. Broder; and if he is out of reach, communicate with the department before you do any work. And yet the hon. gentleman charges this sworn body of men with having stuffed the census. It is a poor compliment to pay to 4,239 men in this Dominion, 1,300 of whom were in the province of Ontario, to say that they joined together as one man to stuff the census; and it was a poor compliment to pay to the reverend gentleman whom he quoted to-day to suppose that men under their instructions and guidance would foster anything of that kind. What are the facts of the case ? Hon. gentlemen opposite were prophets a few years ago. They prophesied a certain increase in the population of this country; and when accused of spending more money than ought to be spent, their justification was that the population had increased wonderfully. Now, these hon. gentlemen are face to face with their prophesies, and they find that they do not agree with the facts; therefore somebody must be indicted. But I am glad to be able to say that the public have paid very little attention to the accusations of the Minister of Trade and Commence. They fell about as dead as his apologetic thesis fell a few

years ago. What are the facts ? The increase in the province of Quebec from 1881 to 1891 was 120,508, while the increase from 1891 to 1901, was 132,444, in round numbers 4,000 more of an increase from the stuffed census to the present census than the previous increase. Now, if the census was stuffed to the extent of 40,000 names, as the hon. gentleman holds, how is it possible for the present census to go so much beyond the natural increase ? And when you turn up ' Hansard ' and quote the language of the Minister of Agriculture, when he was justifying the issue of that Cote circular, -what do we find him saying ? He said that the reason for it was that the French population left the province of Quebec and went to the United States. Why, I thought no person was now leaving this country. That was the reason the hon. gentleman gave for the issue of this circular-to reach the people who were leaving the province and going to the United States-a direct bid to stuff the census. I think there was an interview some time ago with Mr. COte, in which that gentleman gave as a reason why the census of 891 was stuffed, that the enumerators got 3 cents per name. Well, if 3 cents per name induced these gentlemen to stuff the census, I wonder how 5 cents a name works. And when you come to the cost of the census, in 1891 it was not quite $500,000, whereas hon. gentlemen opposite have spent $1,000,000 up to date, aiid they have a year and a half before their work will be completed. I will give the hon. gentleman this advice, although he will have no census to take again, there is no doubt about that : but if he has, let him appoint his own officials, instead of allowing the premier of Ontario to unload upon him some one he wants to get rid of. That is what has happened. Mr. Blue was over the Mining Bureau of the province of Ontario, and the miners wanted to get rid of him, and they loaded him on to the Minister of Agriculture, and he has spent up to date over $1,000,000. Then, look at the number of men employed to take the census. In 1S91 there were some 4,000 odd enumerators, but there are over 8,000 to take the last census. As proof of that I will give you the statement made by the Minister of Agriculture that they appointed an enumerator for each polling sub-division, and there are over 8,000 polling sub-divisions in the Dominion of Canada. Another thing I wish to say-that the hon. gentleman takes evidence ten or eleven years after the fact as proof against men who have taken a solemn affidavit to do a certain piece of work; and the reverend, gentleman who sent in the statements which have been read, do not pretend to say that they are a full census of the people. If the hon. gentleman had read to this House the correspondence connected with the documents from which he tried to make out his ease, he would find that they condemned himself most strongly. Some
of these men gave evidence within three months, and some of these hon. gentlemen here have been hunting for evidence to justify the statement made by the hon. Minister of Trade and Commerce. The name generally applied, I believe, to the men who get up a brief is that of jackal for the counsel employed, and the Minister of Agriculture has been acting in this capacity for his colleague the Minister of Trade and Commerce. These hon. gentlemen had to pull the Minister of Trade and Commerce out of a hole, but it will take more than the Minister of Agriculture to do that.
What are the facts ? The exodus is still going on, to the regret of every honest Canadian. And what kind of men are leaving the country ? Young men educated in our schools, who are sent not only to our colleges but to our high schools and collegiate institutes in order to be fit for the business of life. These are the men who, finding there is no room for them in our commercial centres, have to go to the United States. After the state has educated them and their parents have made sacrifices to send them to school, they cannot find employment in this country, even in this era of boasted prosperity, and have to go to the United States. There is not a man in this country, who is engaged in business, who does not know but too well that there never was a time in the history of the country when it was so difficult to find business openings for young men of education and ability to make their way in commercial life. Let me cite one of these hon.' gentlemen's own witnesses-no doubt an unwilling witness but none the less credible on that account. I hold in my hand the repbi't of the Minister of Education for the province of Ontario. And what does he say regarding our population ? All will admit that an indication of the population of the country is the number of its children. And what do we find ? We find that the number of children of school age-and that age has not been changed since 1892-in Ontario in 1899 was 586,350 as compared with 595,238 in 1892. In other words, at the end of seven years after 1892, there were 8,838 less school children in the province of Ontario than there were seven years previously. There is one of the hon. gentleman's own witnesses. He may repudiate him if he likes, but there can be no doubt that his statement is a correct one. That is the present position. Let xhe Minister of Trade and Commerce give a little attention to these figures and see how they square with the explanation he made throughout the country in justification of our increased expenditure.
The Minister of Agriculture has laid a great deal of stress on the encouragement he claims to have given certain enterprises in this country. Does he pretend that it is he who has led the trade of the country in these matters to which the hon. gentleman has referred. If he does, no one will believe

him. Whatever development has taken place has been due to the efforts of our energetic business men who have been using every effort to push trade along. Does he pretend, for instance, that the cold storage under his control is adequate to the requirements of the country ? Let me inform him where some of our cheese is heated. It is not in the factory, but in travelling from one point to another in the country in order to reach the ocean port, and the heating is due to the absence of those cold storage cars which the hon. gentleman is supposed to provide. The cars were not on hand, supplied with this cold storage, and this cheese had to be put into red hot stations, where they had to wait for this cold storage accommodation. The heating did not take place in the factories. This we have on the authority of Professor Robertson and oiners. I have personal knowledge myself of what lam talking about, and I know that it does not make any difference how good your cheese is, if you get it heated on its way to market you may freeze it as long as you like afterwards, it will not recover its former quality. The hon. gentleman knows well that he started out with one kind of cold storage, and then found he had no ventilation and had to change it. He had to get ventilated cold storage, and that is why the ship-owners do not want to bother with him. They know very well that he does not know exactly what he is going to do.
The MINISTER OP AGRICULTURE The cold storage has never been changed but we have supplied ventilation in the holds of steamers.

Why, the hon. gentleman, in order to explain his failure, told us that over in South Africa they were six years trying to find out how to keep peaches in good condition during shipment, and he is not any more clever than the people in South Africa. He will be six years before he can get a proper system. The' hon. gentleman takes great credit for having tried to help the farmers. But in 1896, when an estimate for cold storage was submitted to the House and when Mr. Poster, who was then acting Minister of Agriculture, wanted these gentlemen to let it go through, they refused, and yet now they talk about their endeavours to promote the interests of the farmers. The hon. gentleman asks us if we ignore the influence of the farmers institutes throughout Ontario.

Certainly not, but he must not forget that the agricultural societies do not take so much stock in what he says as he thinks they do. I find in the ' Hansard ' of 1902 that Mr. Bennett put the hon. gentleman the following question :
Is the government aware that at a meeting held on the 5th day of February, instant, in the city of Toronto, the following resolution was passed unanimously by the Shorthorn Breeders Association.
We, the members of the Dominion Short-hern Breeders Association, at our annual meeting, resolved that the tubercular test is unreliable, unnecessary, and in many cases injurious, and that we urge its discontinuance of the compulsory use of toxine by the Dominion government Department of Agriculture ; and we also fail to see the object now of requiring ninety days quarantine, as there is no contagious disease in Great Britain requiring its enforcement to such a length of. time.
In view of the above action, is it the intention of the government to meet the wishes of the said association ?
What did the minister say in reply ? He said :
It is not the intention of the government to act in the direction indicated by the resolution.
He does not pay much attention to these gentlemen nor do they pay much attention to him. Well, the hon. gentleman afterwards spoke for about a half an hour to these men trying to justify his refusal and they passed a resolution condemning it. So much for these societies view of the administration of the minister, and I think that the Minister of Agriculture of Ontario concurred in their condemnation of his administration. He is not in line with these societies, so that we must just take what he says about these matters with a considerable degree of doubt.
There is another matter to which I wish to refer. The hon. gentleman spoke of the exodus of to-day as being an exodus from south to north, instead of as formerly from north to south. But he omitted to tell us that if lie and his friends had had their way in the past, there would have been no north country for any exodus to go to. That country would never have been opened up, and consequently there would be no people seeking it out as a place for settlement. But they are singing quite a different song now from what they did formerly. It was not so very long ago when they said : Let that country go, it is not worth bothering about. Very well, then hon. gentlemen have to admit that there is an increase in trade largely from the products of that country which was opened up through the efforts of the Conservative party. And when you deduct the bullion and ore, and the flour and wheat, which are the products of the North-west and Manitoba, tlie hon. gentleman's trade shrinks very rapidly. While we are on the subject of quarantine, I may say that the hon. gentleman takes great

credit for having raised the quarantine, or, rather, modified the condition between this country and the United States. I do not know what the hon. gentleman himself says, but his friends on the platform throughout the country say that Hon. Sydney Fisher, a practical farmer, convinced the American people that our cattle were free from disease. But, in the United States the cattle were known at one time to be diseased. Did the Americans convince Hon. Sydney Fisher, the practical farmer, that their cattle were not diseased ? He opened the gates irrespective of that fact, and that is one of the reasons that we cannot get the embargo In the British market raised-the hon. gentleman has put that beyond all possibility. In fact, he has abandoned the attempt, knowing the impossibility of it, since he made this arrangement with the United States. He ought to have looked after Canadian interests, and I do not see much benefit to Canadians in sending a twelve or fourteen dollar animal over to the United States for the Americans to fatten and send over to England as "worth seventy-five or eighty dollars.
The Liberal party all over this country are singing the praises of the hon. minister as a practical farmer. I question whether he has ever been between the plough tails.
I question whether he ever intends to try. But I want to tell the hon. gentleman that in spite of all the boasting of his friends, in spite of all he has said, he cannot show where he has added one article to the curriculum of the agricultural text-books. In the Agriculture Committee, we are dealing with the same subjects that we dealt with in 1896. And you can go a good deal further back. Cato was asked by a person how to get rich and his answer was ' Feed cattle.'
' Feed them how ? '	' Feed them moderately.' This was eighteen hundred and fifty years ago, and the hon. gentleman is discussing that question to-day. But this ' practical farmer ' of whom his friends say so much, does not do anything to fasten the people to the soil. What kind of farmers does he meet ? He meets the farmer who gets up at nine o'clock and goes down about three o'clock to see how his bank account stands, not the poor farmer who* rises before daylight and ploughs his furrow alone. The poor farmer of small means and in debt is not reached by the hon. gentleman. The man who can take hold and use the propositions laid down by the hon. gentleman is the man who has means to put up buildings, to buy machinery and improve his land. But the poor fellow who is looking for shelter rather than for a comfortable house, who wants to find a place to put his cattle where they will be out of the reach of the storm, is overlooked by the hon. gentleman, though he is a ' practical farmer.' That is one reason why our population is going away from the farm. Free corn, which the hon. gentleman talks so much of,
was not intended for the poor fellow I have been speaking of. He can eat Johnny cake, but the bulk of the free corn is for the cattle in the stalls. When this poor fellow puts on his shoulder a bag of grain to go to market, he is overtaken on the way by a full bag of American corn to be sold ahead of him. This is the fellow the hon. gentleman- has overlooked. What does the census show ? That census must be a cause of thought to every loyal Canadian. We know that it will be impossible to assimilate the foreign element coming into this country unless the natural increase of our population is larger than the census shows. We are up against the fact that the foreign element coming into this country, not assimilated by our own population will never have the true Canadian sentiment that should be shared by all our people. Now, in 1901, we had a rural population of 3,349,055, and an urban population of 2,206,001, that is we had 328,464 more of rural than of urban population. But ten years before, in 1891, we had 3,296,141 rural population and 1,537,098 urban population, or a rural population greater than the urban by 1,759,043. We have increased our total population by 530,427, but our population of farmers has increased by only 52,924, and that included the North-west, where hon. gentlemen claim to have sent in, since 1891,
262,000.	In other words, we have put one man on the soil and we have sent 9 to the town. And this under a ' practical farmer.' I can tell you, Mr. Speaker, the hon. gentleman has not ploughed to the end of his furrow yet. His duty is hardly begun. This is a question that every honest Canadian ought to try to solve. It is a serious thing to think that this wide gate is open out of the country, that those who stand at the gate of life are able with less frequency to report a new life in which there may be great possibilities for the future. That question stands for solution not only at the door of the state, but also at the door of the church. You may have volume of trade, but the true assurance of -economic prosperity and of social security is in the increase and assimilation of population.
Now I ^vant to devoite a few minutes to another matter, which the hon. gentleman touched very lightly. It is a question that I do not wonder he touched lightly. I find he was over in England last summer. I was glad to see he was over there. He made a statement there, which is reported in the Lancashire ' Courier,' while he was speaking before the Board of Trade. He told them that we did not want anything for this preference which we are giving them. The right hon. gentleman who leads the government had already made that statement a few years ago. But that is not the end of it. We see Mr. W. T. it. Preston bobbing up a few days ago at the London Chamber of Commerce, and saying, We do not want anything for this. How are public men in

England, however well Inclined they may toe to give Canada a preference in the British markets, to go to their people and ask them to make any sacrifices, when the premier of Canada, the Minister of Agriculture and their agents are singing out, We don't want any preference V It is a difficult task for the public men of England to encourage or advocate a preference to the colonies in face of this Canadian government saying, We don't want it. These gentlemen are not honest in the interests of Canada when they make that statement. They say there is a great deal in sentiment. Well, Sir, if we follow the history of trade in the United States there is very little in sentiment. It is a very strange fact that the trade of the United States for the last forty years has increased and expanded as England's trade and colonial expansion has increased and expanded. The United States' expansion of trade with England has increased as England's has increased. But that is not the history of Canada. These gentlemen should endeavour to put Canada in the same relative position towards England that the United States occupies ; and, Sir, they are not true to the interests' of this country when they make no attempt to do so. If there is one thing more than another that renders high protection necessary in Canada it is the conditions of this country. What are they V As an English writer has said, the conditions which justify protection are, a country with large natural resources undeveloped, a high political and industrial outlook, and late on coming into the markets of industry. That is exactly the position of Canada. We have untold resources undeveloped ; we think we have the prospect of high intellectual and political advancement, and we know we have ability in the [DOT] markets of industry. Therefore, the duty of Canadians is to stand by these conditions and to make the fiscal policy one that w-iil develop those conditions to the highest extent possible.
